reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s use of present-day billionaire philanthropy rates as (weak) evidence against the claim that abundance will shift marginal resources toward altruistic ends. That point is not central to the overall thesis (which leans heavily on broader considerations about convergence, antirealism/realism, trade, threats, blockers), but it does support one sub-argument in §2.3.2, so centrality is low-moderate. The critique has some force: the post-AGI world could differ drastically (advisors, epistemic clarity, institutions, self-modification), so extrapolating from current billionaires is questionable. However, the essay already substantially hedges this evidence (“weakly suggests”, “all else equal”, notes expanded scope for self-interested spending, etc.), so removing/weakening this data point doesn’t strongly damage the author’s overall conclusion about abundance not guaranteeing altruism. Most claims in the critique are plausible and relevant; a mild overstatement is implying the essay treats today’s behavior as invariant psychological fact, when it presents it as limited evidence. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little to no dead weight.
title: Current billionaire giving rates may not generalize to post-AGI conditions
